Design Thinking Participant Worksheet

In this Design Thinking activity, you will redesign the news experience for your partner. Design Thinking is a methodology which takes the design process and applies it to everyday problems, or other work flows. The core tenets of Design Thinking are:

Empathy Define Ideate Prototype Test

To start you will need the following:

  • A couple of sheets of paper, each folded in half. Write your name on the corner of your papers.
  • A pen or pencil
* Don't start until instructed to do so

Step One: The Interview

Empathy
  1. Separate into two groups and define who is in Group A and Group B (try to be even).
  2. Group A will interview Group B for exactly 6 minutes.

    06:00
  3. Group A takes notes from the interview in one side of their paper. Make sure everyone participates and has a chance to weigh in during the interview. The question being asked is,
    “Describe your most recent news consumption experience.” Meaning, what was the last time you consumed the news.
    • How did you consume it?
    • What method/app/device did you use?
    • Where were you?
    • Did it cost money?
    • Etc.
  4. When the timer ends, immediately stop. When everyone is ready, proceed to the next step.

Step Two: Reverse Interview

Empathy
  1. Now Group B will interview Group A for six minutes. Same question.
    • “Describe your most recent news consumption experience.”
    • How did you consume it?
    • What method/app/device did you use?
    • Where were you?
    • Did it cost money?
    06:00
  2. Group B takes notes. When the timer goes off, immediately stop and when everyone is ready proceed, go to the next step.

Step Three: Digging Deeper

Empathy
  1. Next Group A will re-interview Group B, this time for 4 minutes. Same question.
  2. But this time, probe further the emotional aspect. Seek emotion, seek story, seek motivations. Key to design is to learn about the emotional aspect.
    • Was it an enjoyable experience?
    • Was it frustrating?
    • Was it expensive?
    • What were the key motivations for using this method? Convenience, informative, insightful, what?
    04:00
  3. Group A takes notes in their box. When the timer goes off, immediately stop. When everyone is ready proceed, go to the next step.

Step Four: Digging Deeper B->A

Empathy
  1. Next Group B will re-interview Group A for 4 minutes. Same question.
  2. Seek emotion, seek story, seek motivations. Key to design is to learn about the emotional aspect.
    • Was it an enjoyable experience?
    • Was it frustrating?
    • Was it expensive?
    • What were the key motivations for using this method? Convenience, informative, insightful, what?
    04:00
  3. Group B takes notes in their box. When the timer goes off, immediately stop. When everyone is ready proceed, go to the next step.

Step Five: Define the Problem

Define
  1. Next everyone will look at their notes and form a single problem statement. Flip your paper, and make a list of all of the things you think people are trying to accomplish.
    • Needs: Things they are trying to do.
    • Insights: Inferences from what you heard.
  2. Lastly, write out your problem statement in this format:
    [name of person/group] needs a way to [specify need] because [insight]
  3. You each do this on your own. Three minutes.
    03:00
  4. When the timer goes off, immediately stop. When everyone is ready proceed, go to the next step.

Step Six: Sketch Ideas

Ideate/Prototype
  1. Next, on the second half of your paper, you will generate a minimum of five ideas for products or services that could solve the problem statement you wrote out in the previous step. Put them in separate boxes on the page.
         
  2. Do not use words. Only drawings. You must sketch out doodles that describe your ideas.
    • It's okay if you're a terrible artist. Bad doodles sometimes spark creative ideas.
    • You can draw apps, devices, services, flowcharts, whatever.
    • Quantity over quality. The more the better. You can exceed five ideas. Come up with as many as you can, as fast as you can. Stream of consciousness works best in this stage. The more, the better. There is another step to refine your ideas, half-baked is okay.
    08:00
  3. When the timer goes off, immediately stop. When everyone is ready proceed, go to the next step.

Step Seven: Share Ideas

Test
  1. Next, each person in your group will have exactly 3 minutes to share their sketches with the whole group and gather feedback. Don't spend the whole time describing your ideas. You'll need to allot time for reaction and feedback. Take notes on a second sheet of paper. Hold up your sketches to your web cam.
  2. Reset the timer for each person.
    03:00
  3. When everyone is done (12 minutes total) then proceed to the next step.

Step Eight: Revise ideas

Rinse, repeat
  1. Next, take the feedback you got in the previous step and create a single refined idea. You can use a mixture of text and drawings in this part. Your ideas can be extended from one of your earlier drawings, or an entirely new idea. This is what you'll present to the class.
  2. Everyone does this part on their own.
    05:00
  3. When the timer goes off and everyone is done then you may discuss until the host ends the breakout rooms session.
